elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

      

Highlights

   ⋅ Three zinc coordination polymers based on benzenedicarboxylate position isomers were synthesized.   ⋅ A 5-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional diamondoid network.   ⋅ The luminescence and thermal stability.   ⋅ The rigid 4-substituted 1,2,4-triazole ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)benzene.

<ce:para id="p0120" view="all">Three zinc coordination polymers based on benzenedicarboxylate position isomers were synthesized.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0125" view="all">A 5-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional diamondoid network.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0130" view="all">The luminescence and thermal stability.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0135" view="all">The rigid 4-substituted 1,2,4-triazole ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)benzene.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st105">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Three position isomers 1,2-, 1,3-, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate and 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)benzene were used to assembly zinc(II) coordination polymers {[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(btx)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(1,2-bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), {[Zn(btx)(1,3-bdc)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O·(DMF)}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and {[Zn(btx)(1,4-bdc)]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a (3,4,4,4)-connected two-dimensional network with point symbol (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·6)(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·8)(4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·6·10<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>). <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows a two-dimensional (4,4) network. <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibits a 5-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional diamondoid network. The structural versatility shows that the structures of coordination polymers can be tuned by the position isomers ligands. The luminescence and thermal stability were investigated.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Three zinc coordination polymers based on benzenedicarboxylate position isomers were synthesized.

A 5-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional diamondoid network.

The luminescence and thermal stability.

The rigid 4-substituted 1,2,4-triazole ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)benzene.

Abstract

Three position isomers 1,2-, 1,3-, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate and 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)benzene were used to assembly zinc(II) coordination polymers {[Zn2(btx)0.5(1,2-bdc)2(H2O)]⋅H2O} n  (1), {[Zn(btx)(1,3-bdc)]⋅2H2O⋅(DMF)} n  (2) and {[Zn(btx)(1,4-bdc)]⋅3H2O} n  (3). 1 is a (3,4,4,4)-connected two-dimensional network with point symbol (42⋅6)(44⋅62)(43⋅62⋅8)(42⋅6⋅103). 2 shows a two-dimensional (4,4) network. 3 exhibits a 5-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional diamondoid network. The structural versatility shows that the structures of coordination polymers can be tuned by the position isomers ligands. The luminescence and thermal stability were investigated.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st005">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The rational design and synthesis of coordination polymers is of great interest in modern inorganic chemistry stemming from their potential applications as functional materials such as luminescence, catalysis and gas absorption and their intriguing variety of topologies . In order to get such intriguing topologies and functional materials, the crucial step is to employ appropriate organic building blocks as well as metal ions. Because of the diversity of the coordination modes and high structural stability, polycarboxylate ligands are frequently used for the construction of MOFs. The position isomers 1,2-, 1,3, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate are rigid, planar molecules and well bridging ligands in the synthesis of novel MOFs .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rational design and synthesis of coordination polymers is of great interest in modern inorganic chemistry stemming from their potential applications as functional materials such as luminescence, catalysis and gas absorption and their intriguing variety of topologies . In order to get such intriguing topologies and functional materials, the crucial step is to employ appropriate organic building blocks as well as metal ions. Because of the diversity of the coordination modes and high structural stability, polycarboxylate ligands are frequently used for the construction of MOFs. The position isomers 1,2-, 1,3, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate are rigid, planar molecules and well bridging ligands in the synthesis of novel MOFs .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">In the other hand, flexible bidentate N-donors ligands such as bis(imidazole)  and 1-substituted bis(triazole) , and ligands are widely used to construct coordination polymers because flexible ligands can adopt different conformations according to the geometric needs of the different metal ions. In previous work, we synthesized a lot of coordination polymers using flexible 1-substituted bis(triazole) building blocks, such as 1,2-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)ethane (bte) , 1,3-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propane (btp) , 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb)  and 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bbtz) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the other hand, flexible bidentate N-donors ligands such as bis(imidazole)  and 1-substituted bis(triazole) , and ligands are widely used to construct coordination polymers because flexible ligands can adopt different conformations according to the geometric needs of the different metal ions. In previous work, we synthesized a lot of coordination polymers using flexible 1-substituted bis(triazole) building blocks, such as 1,2-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)ethane (bte) , 1,3-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propane (btp) , 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb)  and 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (bbtz) .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">In contrast to 1-substituted-1,2,4-triazole derivatives, the research of coordination polymers based on 4-substituted-1,2,4-triazole derivatives is only just beginning . We also achieved a series of fantastic frameworks based on flexible 4-substituted-1,2,4-triazole ligand 1,2-bis(1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)ethane (btre) , such as {[Cd(btre)Cl]·OH}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>, {[Cd(btre)Cl][CdCl(dca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> and {[Zn(btre)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(OH-bdc)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·1.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>. The 4-substituted-1,2,4-triazole bridging ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)benzene (btx) should be a good rigid building block to construct coordination polymers with novel structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In contrast to 1-substituted-1,2,4-triazole derivatives, the research of coordination polymers based on 4-substituted-1,2,4-triazole derivatives is only just beginning . We also achieved a series of fantastic frameworks based on flexible 4-substituted-1,2,4-triazole ligand 1,2-bis(1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)ethane (btre) , such as {[Cd(btre)Cl]⋅OH} n , {[Cd(btre)Cl][CdCl(dca)2]⋅0.5H2O} n  and {[Zn(btre)0.5(OH-bdc)(H2O)2]⋅1.5H2O} n . The 4-substituted-1,2,4-triazole bridging ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)benzene (btx) should be a good rigid building block to construct coordination polymers with novel structures.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

Materials and general methods

All reagents were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses for C, H and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. IR spectra were obtained for KBr pellets on a Nicolet 170SX FT-IR spectrophotometer in the 4000-400cm-1 region. The luminescence measurements were carried out in the solid state at room temperature and the spectra were collected with a Perkin-Elmer LS50B spectrofluorimeter. TGA was carried out using a Thermal Analyst 2100 TA Instrument and SDT 2960 Simultaneous TGA-DTA Instrument in flowing dinitrogen at a heating rate of 10°C/min.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st035">X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Suitable single crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. The diffraction data were collected on the Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometers with graphite monochromated Mo Ka radiation. Intensities were collected by the ω scan technique. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique (SHELXTL-97) . The positions of hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were placed in their geometrically idealized positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. The parameters of the crystal data collection and refinement of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Suitable single crystals of 1, 2 and 3 were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. The diffraction data were collected on the Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometers with graphite monochromated Mo Ka radiation. Intensities were collected by the ω scan technique. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique (SHELXTL-97) . The positions of hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were placed in their geometrically idealized positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. The parameters of the crystal data collection and refinement of 1, 2 and 3 are given in  . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in  .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st040">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st045">Crystal structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic system with <ce:bold>C</ce:bold>2/c space group. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consists of two Zn(II) atoms, half btx, two 1,2-bdc, one coordination water and disordered lattice water molecules. The Zn1(II) atom is five-coordinated and surrounded by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from three 1,2-bdc, one oxygen atom from coordination water and one triazole nitrogen atom from btx ligand in a distorted trigonalbipyramidal geometry (ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>). The Zn2(II) atom is four-coordinated and surrounded by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from four 1,2-bdc ligands in a distorted tetrahedral geometry (ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>). There are two kinds of 1,2-bdc ligands. One carboxylate group (O1O2) of one 1,2-bdc ligand shows bidentate coordination mode and coordinates two Zn(II) atoms. The other carboxylate group (O3O4) acts as monodentate coordination mode and links one Zn(II) atom. Two carboxylate groups (O5O6 and O7O8) of the other 1,2-bdc ligand both show bidentate coordination mode and coordinates two Zn(II) atoms. Therefore two kind of 1,2-bdc ligands show tridentate and tetradentate coordination modes, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal structures

Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit of 1 consists of two Zn(II) atoms, half btx, two 1,2-bdc, one coordination water and disordered lattice water molecules. The Zn1(II) atom is five-coordinated and surrounded by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from three 1,2-bdc, one oxygen atom from coordination water and one triazole nitrogen atom from btx ligand in a distorted trigonalbipyramidal geometry (ZnO4N) ( ). The Zn2(II) atom is four-coordinated and surrounded by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from four 1,2-bdc ligands in a distorted tetrahedral geometry (ZnO4). There are two kinds of 1,2-bdc ligands. One carboxylate group (O1O2) of one 1,2-bdc ligand shows bidentate coordination mode and coordinates two Zn(II) atoms. The other carboxylate group (O3O4) acts as monodentate coordination mode and links one Zn(II) atom. Two carboxylate groups (O5O6 and O7O8) of the other 1,2-bdc ligand both show bidentate coordination mode and coordinates two Zn(II) atoms. Therefore two kind of 1,2-bdc ligands show tridentate and tetradentate coordination modes, respectively.

Two adjacent [Zn(1,2-bdc)0.5] n  one-dimensional chains are joined by tetradentate 1,2-bdc ligands to construct new [Zn2(1,2-bdc)2] n  one-dimensional tape ( ). Two kinds of 1,2-bdc ligands exhibit the 3- and 4-connected, respectively. Each btx ligand is 2-connected node. The [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(btx)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(1,2-bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>

<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). Each 1,3-bdc acts as bis-monodentate bridging ligand and link two Zn(II) atoms to extend to form [Zn(1,3-bdc)]<ce:italic>

</ce:italic> one dimensional chain with the Zn⋯Zn distance of 10.029(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Each btx shows as bis-monodentate bridging ligand and connects [Zn(1,3-bdc)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> one dimensional chains to construct [Zn(btx)(1,3-bdc)]<ce:italic>

elements.clean_text: 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic system with Pbcm space group. The asymmetric unit of 2 consists of half Zn(II) atom, half btx, half 1,3-bdc, one lattice water one DMF. Each Zn(II) atom is four-coordinated and surrounded by two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two 1,3-bdc and two triazole nitrogen atoms from two btx ligands in a distorted tetrahedral geometry (ZnO2N2) ( ). Each 1,3-bdc acts as bis-monodentate bridging ligand and link two Zn(II) atoms to extend to form [Zn(1,3-bdc)] n  one dimensional chain with the Zn⋯Zn distance of 10.029(2)Å. Each btx shows as bis-monodentate bridging ligand and connects [Zn(1,3-bdc)] n  one dimensional chains to construct [Zn(btx)(1,3-bdc)] n  two-dimensional (4,4) network with the Zn⋯Zn distance of 13.681(2)Å ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The two-dimensional layers parallel stack along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis direction and form one-dimensional channels ca. 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>). The lattice water and DMF molecules are located at the channels and stabilize the network via the hydrogen binding interactions between lattice and carboxylate oxygen atoms or oxygen atoms from DMF molecules ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The two-dimensional layers parallel stack along the a-axis direction and form one-dimensional channels ca. 6×9Å ( ). The lattice water and DMF molecules are located at the channels and stabilize the network via the hydrogen binding interactions between lattice and carboxylate oxygen atoms or oxygen atoms from DMF molecules ().

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">
<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is short communication . For comparison, the structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is simply presented below. The Zn(II) atom in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is five-coordinated and surrounded by two triazole nitrogen atoms from two btx and three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two 1,4-bdc ligands in a distorted trigonalbipyramidal geometry (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>). Each Zn(II) center connects four Zn(II) centers through two btx and two 1,4-bdc bridges in a tetrahedral mode and extend to construction of a three-dimensional network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>). The three-dimensional motif can be simplified as a four-connected 6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup> diamondoid topological net (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor>) . Because the single diamondoid network has large spacious voids, it allows adjacent frameworks to interpenetrate to give a 5-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional diamondoid network . The degrees of the diamondoid nets interpenetration ranging from 2- to 11-fold are well-known and have been reported , but the 5-fold interpenetrating MOFs in the presence of the mixed organic ligands with different lengths is relatively rare .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: 3 is short communication . For comparison, the structure of 3 is simply presented below. The Zn(II) atom in 3 is five-coordinated and surrounded by two triazole nitrogen atoms from two btx and three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two 1,4-bdc ligands in a distorted trigonalbipyramidal geometry ( ). Each Zn(II) center connects four Zn(II) centers through two btx and two 1,4-bdc bridges in a tetrahedral mode and extend to construction of a three-dimensional network ( ). The three-dimensional motif can be simplified as a four-connected 66 diamondoid topological net ( ) . Because the single diamondoid network has large spacious voids, it allows adjacent frameworks to interpenetrate to give a 5-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional diamondoid network . The degrees of the diamondoid nets interpenetration ranging from 2- to 11-fold are well-known and have been reported , but the 5-fold interpenetrating MOFs in the presence of the mixed organic ligands with different lengths is relatively rare .

<ce:section-title id="st050">Luminescence</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The solid state photoluminescence properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and the free btx ligand were investigated at room temperature. The btx displays the emission band at 432<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 370<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, which can probably be assigned to the π–π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> transitions . <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows emission maximum at 415<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm emission upon excitation at 333<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>). No emission of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was observed at the same experimental condition. <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibit the emission bands maximum at 394<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and a shoulder peak at 454<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, upon excitation at 345<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. The free 1,2-H2bdc, 1,3-H2bdc and 1,4-H2bdc exhibit emissions at 375, 370 and 390<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively, according to the literature . Because the Zn(II) ion is difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to the d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> configuration, the emissions are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) . The emission at 415<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be attributed to the emission of btx and 1,2-bdc combination. The emissions at 394 and 454<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm can be tentatively attributed to the intra-ligand charge transition for 1,4-bdc and btx, respectively , because the emission at 394<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is near to that of 1,4-bdc (390<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) . The emission at 454<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> shows the obvious red shift 22<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm compare to free btx ligand.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence

The solid state photoluminescence properties of 1, 2, 3 and the free btx ligand were investigated at room temperature. The btx displays the emission band at 432nm upon excitation at 370nm, which can probably be assigned to the π-π∗ transitions . 1 shows emission maximum at 415nm emission upon excitation at 333nm ( ). No emission of 2 was observed at the same experimental condition. 3 exhibit the emission bands maximum at 394nm and a shoulder peak at 454nm, upon excitation at 345nm. The free 1,2-H2bdc, 1,3-H2bdc and 1,4-H2bdc exhibit emissions at 375, 370 and 390nm, respectively, according to the literature . Because the Zn(II) ion is difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to the d10 configuration, the emissions are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) . The emission at 415nm for 1 can be attributed to the emission of btx and 1,2-bdc combination. The emissions at 394 and 454nm can be tentatively attributed to the intra-ligand charge transition for 1,4-bdc and btx, respectively , because the emission at 394nm for 3 is near to that of 1,4-bdc (390nm) . The emission at 454nm for 3 shows the obvious red shift 22nm compare to free btx ligand.

Thermal analysis

In the TG curve of 1 ( ), the lattice water molecules were lost from 45 to 124°C (Calcd.: 5.99%, found: 5.86%). The anhydrous substance is stable upon heating to 300°C. Then the weight decrease continuously happened and did not end until to 600°C. The lattice water and DMF molecules of 2 were continuously lost from 45 to 184°C (Calcd.: 19.81%, found: 19.94%). The anhydrous substance is stable upon heating to 303°C. Then the weight decrease continuously happened and did not end until to 600°C. The lattice water molecules of 3 were lost from 45 to 180°C (Calcd.: 10.90%, found: 10.76%). The anhydrous substance is stable upon heating to 335°C. Then the weight decrease continuously happened and did not end until to 600°C.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st060">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">In summary, three Zn(II) coordination polymers were synthesized by the combination of position isomers 1,2-, 1,3-, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate and 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)benzene. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a (3,4,4,4)-connected two-dimensional network. <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows a two-dimensional (4,4) network. <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> constructs a 5-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional diamondoid network. The structural versatility of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> shows that the structures of coordination polymers can be tuned by the position isomer ligands. Further syntheses and structural studies of novel coordination polymer with combination of triazole ligands and polycarboxylate ligands are also under way in our laboratory.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, three Zn(II) coordination polymers were synthesized by the combination of position isomers 1,2-, 1,3-, 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate and 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)benzene. 1 is a (3,4,4,4)-connected two-dimensional network. 2 shows a two-dimensional (4,4) network. 3 constructs a 5-fold interpenetrated three-dimensional diamondoid network. The structural versatility of 1, 2, and 3 shows that the structures of coordination polymers can be tuned by the position isomer ligands. Further syntheses and structural studies of novel coordination polymer with combination of triazole ligands and polycarboxylate ligands are also under way in our laboratory.

Synthesis of {[Zn2(btx)0.5(1,2-bdc)2(H2O)]⋅H2O} n  (1)

A solution of 1,2-H2bdc (0.2mmol) in 10mL of H2O was adjusted to pH 6 with 0.35mL of a 1.0M NaOH solution and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.2mmol) was added with stirring. Then 5mL DMF solution of btx (0.1mmol) was added and continuously stirred for 10min. The mixture solution was filtered and stood for one month to give colorless single crystals of 1 (0.041g, 68% yield). Anal. Calcd. for C21H16N3O10Zn2 (1) C, 41.96; H, 2.68; N, 6.99. Found: C, 41.82%; H, 2.61%; N, 6.91%. IR data (cm-1): 3436m, 1621s, 1542s, 1487w, 1447w, 1408s, 1257w, 1087w, 1056w, 843w, 758m, 710w, 661w, 503w.

Synthesis of {[Zn(btx)(1,3-bdc)]⋅2H2O⋅(DMF)} n  (2)

A solution of 1,3-H2bdc (0.2mmol) in 10mL of H2O was adjusted to pH 6 with 0.35mL of a 1.0M NaOH solution and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.2mmol) was added with stirring. Then 5mL DMF solution of btx (0.2mmol) was added and continuously stirred for 10min. The mixture solution was filtered and stood for one month to give colorless single crystals of 2 (0.067g, 61% yield). Anal. Calcd. for C21H23N7O7Zn (2) C, 45.79; H, 4.21; N, 7.80. Found: C, 45.65%; H, 4.13%; N, 7.72%. IR data (cm-1): 3382s, 3164m, 1621s, 1566s, 1448w, 1384s, 1244w, 1156w, 1099w, 1044w, 849w, 747w, 722m, 637w, 540w.

A solution of 1,4-H2bdc (0.2mmol) in 10mL of H2O was adjusted to pH 6 with 0.35mL of a 1.0M NaOH solution and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.2mmol) was added with stirring. Then 5mL DMF solution of btx (0.2mmol) was added and continuously stirred for 10min. The mixture solution was filtered and stood for one month to give colorless single crystals of 3 (0.064g, 65% yield). Anal. Calcd. for C18H18N6O7Zn (3) C, 43.61; H, 3.66; N, 16.96. Found: C, 43.52%; H, 3.60%; N, 16.89%. IR data (cm-1): 3430s, 1572s, 1542s, 1437w, 1390s, 1318w, 1257w, 1099m, 1050w, 1013w, 837m, 752m, 625w, 528w.
